questions.question_text: How many bits is Source Port Number in TCP Header packet?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
From the official specification for TCP, RFC 793 (IETF).
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-tcpm-rfc793bis-25.html

Answer: A. 16

Explanation:

(A) ✅ 16 - The Source Port Number field in a TCP header is 16 bits long.
(B) ❌ 32 - No field in the TCP header is 32 bits for port numbers.
(C) ❌ 48 - Port numbers do not require 48-bit representation.
(D) ❌ 64 - TCP uses 16-bit port numbers, not 64-bit values.

-----
If you agree, please UPVOTE.
Each time you upvote someone with a yellow "SELECTED ANSWER: " banner (like me) your vote is added to the Community Vote Distribution, which helps the community by crowdsourcing correct answers.

The correct answer is A. 16.
The Source Port Number in a TCP Header packet is a 16-bit field, which means it is 16 bits long. This field identifies the port number on the source device that is used to initiate the TCP connection.
Here's a brief overview of the other options:
B. 32 bits is the length of the Sequence Number and Acknowledgment Number fields in the TCP Header.
C. 48 bits is not a standard field length in the TCP Header.
D. 64 bits is the length of the Timestamps option in the TCP Header, which is optional and not related to the Source Port Number.
The TCP Header format is defined in RFC 793, and the Source Port Number is specified as a 16-bit field in Section 3.1 of that document.
A > Source TCP port number (2 bytes or 16 bits)

questions.question_text: With the standard Linux second extended file system (Ext2fs), a file is deleted when the inode internal link count reaches ________.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This Linux book here explains it
https://www.amazon.com/CompTIA-Linux-Certification-Second-XK0-005-ebook/dp/B0BKTVGWMN/ if 1, file still exists

With the standard Linux second extended file system (Ext2fs), a file is deleted when the inode internal link count reaches 0.

Explanation:
In the Linux second extended file system (Ext2fs), an inode is a data structure that stores information about a file, such as its permissions, ownership, size, and location on disk. Each file in the file system is represented by an inode.

The inode internal link count is a field within the inode that counts the number of hard links pointing to the inode. When a new hard link is created to a file, the inode internal link count is incremented by 1. When a hard link is deleted, the inode internal link count is decremented by 1.

When the inode internal link count reaches 0, it means that there are no more hard links pointing to the file. This indicates that the file is no longer in use and can be deleted. At this point, the file system marks the inode and the blocks containing the file's data as available for reuse.

Therefore, with the standard Linux second extended file system (Ext2fs), a file is deleted when the inode internal link count reaches 0.

choices.B: Only Windows systems will reply to this scan
choices.C: A switched network will not respond to packets sent to the broadcast address
choices.A: Only IBM AS/400 will reply to this scan
choices.D: Only Unix and Unix-like systems will reply to this scan

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer: C. A switched network will not respond to packets sent to the broadcast address

Explanation:
(A) ❌ Only IBM AS/400 will reply to this scan - The issue is not specific to AS/400 systems.
(B) ❌ Only Windows systems will reply to this scan - Windows does not restrict replies to ICMP broadcast packets.
(C) ✅ A switched network will not respond to packets sent to the broadcast address - Switches do not forward broadcast traffic, limiting the responses.
(D) ❌ Only Unix and Unix-like systems will reply to this scan - The issue is network infrastructure, not the OS type.

-----
If you agree, please UPVOTE.
Each time you upvote someone with a yellow "SELECTED ANSWER: " banner (like me) your vote is added to the Community Vote Distribution, which helps the community by crowdsourcing correct answers.

Selected Answer: C
In a switched network, switches do not forward broadcast packets to all ports. Instead, they only send them to the specific port where the destination host is located.
Switches reduce broadcast traffic C is correct

Selected Answer: C
A switched network will not respond to packets sent to the broadcast address. When a packet is sent to the broadcast address on a switched network, the switch will only forward the packet out to the ports that are connected to devices that have requested the broadcast packet, instead of flooding it to all ports like on a hub network. As a result, only a few hosts that requested the broadcast packet will respond, and not all hosts on the network.

questions.question_text: After passively scanning the network of Department of Defense (DoD), you switch over to active scanning to identify live hosts on their network. DoD is a large organization and should respond to any number of scans. You start an ICMP ping sweep by sending an IP packet to the broadcast address. Only five hosts respond to your ICMP pings; definitely not the number of hosts you were expecting. Why did this ping sweep only produce a few responses?

choices.D: Change the default community string names
choices.A: Block all internal MAC address from using SNMP

discussion.content:
Meta AI
The correct answer is D. Change the default community string names.
SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) uses community strings as passwords to authenticate access to network devices. The default community strings are well-known ("public" for read-only access and "private" for read-write access), making them easily guessable by attackers. Changing the default community string names to strong, unique passwords will significantly improve SNMP security.

questions.question_text: Your company's network just finished going through a SAS 70 audit. This audit reported that overall, your network is secure, but there are some areas that needs improvement. The major area was SNMP security. The audit company recommended turning off SNMP, but that is not an option since you have so many remote nodes to keep track of. What step could you take to help secure SNMP on your network?
